To prove that there is no largest integer using contradiction, assume the opposite: there exists a largest integer \( N \). According to the problem, for any integer \( n \), there exists an integer \( m \) such that \( m > n \). If \( n = N \), then \( m \) must be greater than \( N \), which contradicts the assumption that \( N \) is the largest. Therefore, no largest integer exists.
